title: Do you know people who don't use smart phones? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t use a smart phone. I use a very simple flip phone that makes calls and sends text messages. It’s also only a year old, but that’s only because I moved to Norway so I needed a new phone. The reasons why are very simple: It’s smaller and more durable than a smart phone, and all I need to do to make a call is flip it open and begin pressing numbers. It withstands bumps and spills a lot easier, and the display isn’t all covered in fingerprints. I can drop the phone and the battery will not pop out. The phone itself is a lot cheaper to replace if it ever got stolen or damaged. I also like to have a phone with actual real buttons. Actual, real, buttons, that you can literally push, not a screen that you have to tap and calibrate. It feels better in my hand. I’ve had a touch screen only phone before, and I hated everything about it, and dealt with it for years. I gave it a chance. It never grew on me. And I usually have my laptop with me, if I ever needed to go online or do something that requires a computer. I’m not going to fiddle with a smartphone while I am driving or at work anyway, and at school, I need a full laptop to help me do my tasks. At no point during my day would I need a smart phone. It’s an inferior computer, and an inferior phone. Keeping them separate makes both things a lot better for me. This may not be the case for you, maybe you have a lot of time during the day where you’re standing around and need to get online or tweet or whatever, or maybe you get lost easily and require a GPS to navigate, instead of the old fashioned way of finding out where you’re going before you leave. None of the things you typically use a smart phone for fit easily into my life to justify having an inferior phone/computer, so it’s a personal preference. I also think people treat their phones like they treat their cars, they want to get the slickest newest model that looks impressive and expensive so they can show them off, and then the next year they get the newest model again. I just want a phone that works as a phone, I just want a car that gets me from A to B, I just want a computer that allows me to see the full screen and allows me to type on a real keyboard. I don’t want the latest and greatest gadget that costs 10 times as much, only to get bored with it in a week and replace it next year just for the sake of looking top of the line. People have yet to show me something their smartphone does that would make me want to have one. That’s just me. You do you.

I know a few people without smart phones. In fact, up until 5 months ago I was one of those people. What changed? I started college in one of the major cities in the US. I'm very directionally and geographically challenged; I have been lost in my own neighborhood more times than I'm proud of. My parents thought it might be a good idea for me to have a navigation system and a device that's more convenient in case of emergencies. I am ever so glad they bought me a phone for my 18th birthday. The person closest to me who doesn't use a smart phone is my boyfriend. He used to own one many years ago, but hated it. He now has a prepaid flip phone phone from Walmart and loves it. Many of my teachers in high school didn't have smart phones either. They had regular old flip phones and knew how to use them quite well. Many of the kids in my high school didn't have smart phones. Granted, the percentage of kids living under the poverty line at my old high school is around 34% and some kids just can't afford to have an expensive phone. I know less people who do not own smart phones in my current community at college than I do back home. I go to an expensive university in the middle of a huge city where most people use smart phones. At home, I live in a small town in a sparsely populated area where cell service doesn't work when you hit outside of city limits. Pretty simple to figure out, if you ask me.

Yes. Me. A year ago I had a Samsung, while I was in town I dropped it and needed to phone my Father urgently on a different matter, so I hopped into the EE store and quickly bought this for £10.  A few weeks later I found myself still using the same phone quite happily. I also discovered that I wasn’t constantly pulling my phone out to check Facebook every 10/20 minutes. I would only use Facebook on my mobile if I was out and about, rarely on my laptop in my house, and now I don’t have Facebook anymore, I discovered I wasn’t using it at all and I wasn’t missing anything, so I de-activated my Facebook and haven’t looked back. Also my anxiety and some insecurities have if not all, nearly gone as that what Facebook does to us, we constantly compare ourselves whether it’s consciously or sub-consciously to other peoples (dare I say fake) Facebook life. Don’t get me wrong, Facebook has its good points, but ever since I dropped my smart phone on that wet, Saturday afternoon in Buchanan Street, Glasgow, I have been much more productive in my life. Whenever I sit and wait for the train, nowadays instead of taking my phone out and reading on peoples Facebook posts (which let’s be honest, I honestly do not care about), I sit and read a book which is far more interesting. And for Music? Just bought myself a cheap second hand I-Pod.

Yes, I see one every morning in the mirror. Some bio Data I am a 49 year old male, living in the State of Washington in a pretty good sized town, I have a laptop, a desktop, a kindle paperwhite ebook reader, and a kindle fire HDX (two generations old). So I obviously don’t have a problem with tech. I have a samsung flip phone, and i don’t even use it much. See, I have to be a little careful how I spend money and I can’t see adding somewhere in the range of $60 - $100 per month for a smartphone (talk/text/data) plan especially when I don’t spend a lot of time on the phone. My Tablets are wifi, and that is common enough that If I need to pop online to check something I generally can (and it’s costs nothing for me to do so).

Yes! Most of the members of the radio controlled model aircraft club I belong to, who despite being fantastic at building and flying their lovely planes, are luddites in other aspects of their lives. More, they only use cheques or cash to pay for things or receive money. It makes paying our membership dues a nightmare (I discarded our chequebook years ago), whilst lack of smartphones makes it hard to organise events or use non text messaging to communicate with anyone at the field to get an accurate weather or turnout check. I should point out most are in their 60s or higher and retired. Us younguns have created a rift in the airspace time contiuum with our high end smartphones, racing drones and PayPal accounts!

Yes, several people. I myself used only a flip phone until 2 years ago. If you use a lot of cell data, the costs go up quite quickly. I had a laptop and an IPod touch that worked with wifi, which I had access to almost everywhere (work, home, many businesses) so I did not need cell data. I now have two unlocked phones, an iPhone and an Android, trying out tow cheap MVNOs now that you can get decent phones without pay a huge amount of money over year. (One is $100/year after a $200 phone, the other is a about $24/month including fees, for unlimited talk/text + $10/GB of data, phone was $250.

Yes i know some people who don't use mobile phones. Don't be so surprised about that, these people are still living, they are not rare in these days . They don't used it because they have not much interest in that they think that they have to talk with people so they used simple phones  ,in that they also can take selfie ,do messages,used calci… Also One main reason is that they might change their path/goal by excessive use of it. Whole day they used and searching waste stuffs, that's why they not used snartphones. Infact my roommate also not have any smartphone

My kids don’t yet have a smart phone. They are 10, 7, and 5 years of age. My parents have a smart phone but certainly don’t ‘use it’ other than giving and receiving phone calls and some occasional text messaging. So I would be interested in seeing the stats on baby boomers and their use of smart phones and kids age 10 and younger (middle school is usually when I see kids using smart phones) as I know that the gap is getting smaller and smaller. It’s amazing how fast culture has changed as it has only been 10 years (I believe) since the iPhone came out! Take care, Nathan Buhl

I use a flip phone because: I hardly ever talk on the phone.I have an iPad and a laptop and almost never go any place where I would need a smart phone to access the internet or any reason to need to. I don’t need GPS — I already know how to get there.The battery hold a charge for days.It’s cheap.It’s small.I can text with it and take photos which I send to my iPad.For six months of the year, I live in a rural area with iffy cell service. I seem to get much more reliable service with the flip phone than with everybody else in the area who has a smart phone (and it’s really annoying trying to talk to them because their words drop out constantly).The one thing that I might want a smart phone for is for displaying photos quickly.

:-) I have 3 grandsons (ages 1, 2, 5) they do not use smart phones. Although the 2 older ones are the masters of some apps on the iPad. Then there are our parents (of my wife and me, older than 84, 86, 87, 91), they use smart phones, but do not use any of the features which turns a mobile phone into a smart phone. Mainly because the text on the screen and the buttons are not big enough for their hands or their touches are not firm enough. Other than these two age groups I have not seen a person without a smart phone for a long time now.

Yes - myself. I collect vintage mobil GSM phones and take great pleasure in using my StarTAC and other 25+ year old flip phones. About the only modern feature I miss is the loudspeaker function as my hearing is not now quite as good as it was 30 years back. If I loose one it’s no big deal as I don’t also loose a whole lot of confidential data that I used to keep in a modern smartphone’s PDA functions.

I bought my first cell phone, a Nokia, back in 1997. I am now using my second cell phone, also a Nokia. Neither are smart phones and neither ever broke down. My daughter is now in possession of her third smart phone, an iPhone 7. My son’s second phone is a Samsung. He is now looking into buying a Galaxy S7 and I told him okay if he intends to pay for the rebuild cost should the house gets burned down. Total cost of my two Nokia phones were $200 plus tax. A fraction of what I paid for my kids’ smart phones. I guess they are smarter than I am.

Just 5 years ago from today I was not using any smartphone myself.there js a huge class of poeple who are still using nokias keypad simple mobiles no touch most of then are old people and countries who are underdeveloped etc. Or people whos jobs are dangerous and they can lose the mobile anytime or they need the mobile very strong whoch could not break and touch screen phones are still not so strong minimum a low budget phone so yes there are different classes of people which dont want to use smartphone or Those who cannot use a smartphone because of the cobdition of their job is not suitable for smartphones.

My wife and I have flip phones; our 30-yo daughter has a smartphone. She’s been through a lot more smartphones than we’ve been through flip phones. I have a laptop at the office and we both have one at home. The two places are 30 minutes apart. For 30 minutes, I’ll read a book, or a paper I’ve printed out. Once in a while I get lost, even in Manhattan, and briefly wish I had a mapping app on my phone.

Yes, one of the programmers I work with still uses a pre-smartphone Nokia that he is really proud of. He loves the fact that the battery lasts for days without charging and that it does the basics that phones should do (phone calls, texts and play Snake). He is active on social media, owns laptop, tablet and a nice gaming PC but really has no desire to own a smartphone.

My wife and I have flip phones, we are not interested in smart phones and have no need for one. I am 67, my wife is 68. I do not text and hate the idea, I value conversation. I own a small hardware store, and I am coordinating building applications that will change telecommunication security, so I am well aware that smart phones are omnipresent. I already spend plenty of time on the computer at work and home.

Smartphones with latest technologies are an integral part of new generation. But now in India the number of mobile phones are higher than the toilets in the country. So people belonging to the low income groups and educational level are also using mobile phones widely. In village level most of the mobile phones using are the ones with basic facilities only. As a senior official I was appointed as the presiding officer for a booth in the election to the state assembly in may 2016. It was mandatory for all presiding officers to have smart phones to down load certain software for the smooth functioning of the election. I did not had a smart phone at that time so I used my colleague’s smart phone. But eventually the down loads failed due to poor net connectivity and instead of that old platforms were used. But later only I bought one and so now I am connected to quora. Thanks to smart phones.

I have never had a cell phone. My work requires me to take out a company flip phone when I leave my building, though I’m only out a couple of times a week. I feel no need to make phone calls most of the time, so my family’s land line covers me. Personal messages wait for me on my email or Facebook until the evening.

Unless they switched over, yes my younger brother and his wife, my apologies, but no Smart device or even Laptop will ever replace a Desktop/PC, for 1 thing even those Website/Applications that claim to be SD compatible in many ways are not, partially, but not entirely.

My dad , till two weeks back. Now I have made him a captive of social media where he gets more fed up of wholesale whatsapp messages of his friends , uncanny wishing of good mornings and nights by those who he would wish away in his sleep and to the world where double tick intrusions make or break relationships. Pray we come out of. Of course, I will change the setting to offer him some privacy and relief …soon :)

Find me a smart phone that will survive in the black hole that is my trouser pocket, keep it’s charge for over a week and work in an emergency if my fingers are wet or covered in blood. Oh and the one I’ve had for the last few years cost me 99p and about£10 in credit a year. Going to a dark corner to hide whenever I have to answer it in public is a bit of an issue but better that than not having it on me in an emergency.

Yes , I do know some one who don`t use smart phone . She is called Sam , she don`t know anything about phones and she never opened Facebook at all . when she told me i was so shooked . I told myself ; Wow she don`t has a smart phone and she never saw facebook Omg .
Yes; I don’t have one, and I don’t want one. But I would miss our i-pad if it was gone.
Either one who cannot afford a smartphone or who is illiterate.
Yes, me.
